title: Quiz 6: Research Methodology & Design
description: Experimental, Quasi-experimental, Survey, and Descriptive designs.

questions.question: Which three characteristics define a True Experimental Design?
questions.explanation: True experimental designs require manipulation, control, and randomization.

questions.question: Which design involves manipulation of an independent variable but lacks randomization or a control group?
questions.explanation: Quasi-experimental designs manipulate variables but lack full randomization/control.

questions.question: Match the specific design with its description.

pairs.right: Periodic observations with treatment in between
Similar to pre-post test but no random assignment
Links present outcome to past events

questions.explanation: Time-series uses periodic observations, Non-equivalent lacks randomization, Retrospective looks back, Prospective looks forward.
questions.hint: Consider the timing and structure of each design.

questions.question: A ___BLANK___ study determines the reasons or causes for the current status of a phenomenon where experimentation is not possible.
questions.explanation: Causal-comparative studies determine causes when experimentation isn't possible.
questions.hint: Think about comparing causes without manipulation.

questions.question: Descriptive research involves manipulation of variables to determine cause and effect.
questions.explanation: Descriptive research observes variables as they are; it does not manipulate them.

questions.question: Which of the following are types of Longitudinal Research? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Panel, Cohort, and Time Series are longitudinal. Cross-sectional is not.
questions.hint: Think about research conducted over time.

questions.question: What type of study collects data from a sample at one specific point in time?
questions.explanation: Cross-sectional studies take a 'snapshot' of a population.
questions.hint: Think about taking a single 'picture' of the population.

questions.question: Which design is most appropriate for establishing causality?
questions.explanation: Experimental designs are best for establishing cause-and-effect relationships.
questions.hint: Think about determining what causes what.

questions.question: Case studies allow for statistical validation and generalization to the wider population.
questions.explanation: Case studies focus on depth of a few cases, making statistical generalization difficult.
questions.hint: Case studies provide depth, not statistical generalization.

questions.question: In a survey, 'Correlation' research attempts to:
questions.explanation: Correlation research determines relationships between variables.
questions.hint: Think about how variables relate to each other.
